question: How long has Ariana Wilson been with the San Francisco Fire Department?
answer: Ariana Wilson has been employed with the San Francisco Fire Department for the past 7 years and volunteered with them for about two and a half years prior.
source_text: hello my name is Ariana Wilson I am a San Francisco firefighter with the San Francisco Fire Department Ive been employed with them for the past 7 years prior to that volunteered with them for about two and a half years

question: Where did Ariana Wilson grow up?
answer: Ariana Wilson was born on Trader Street, grew up most of her life on Ocean Avenue, and spent the latter part of her life in the Panhandle region.
source_text: I was born on Trader Street and then grew up most of my life on Ocean Avenue and then spent the latter part of my life over in the panan region

question: How did Ariana Wilson manage housing during her time at the fire academy?
answer: Ariana Wilson stayed with her dad through the fire academy due to expenses around housing in the city.
source_text: when I got hired with the fire department I ended up actually staying with my dad through the fire academy just due to expenses around housing in the city

question: How did Ariana Wilson secure housing after graduating from the fire academy?
answer: After graduating, Ariana Wilson was able to rent a unit in a building that her grandmother purchased a long time ago.
source_text: luckily after I graduated we were lucky enough to have a building that my grandmother purchased a very long time ago and so I was able to rent a unit in that building for my family

question: What is the general housing situation in San Francisco according to Ariana Wilson?
answer: San Francisco is not a very affordable city. Most of Ariana's friends have two or three roommates, some live in co-ops with about 10 to 12 people, and some coworkers have had to leave the city to afford rent.
source_text: so in general San Francisco is not a very affordable City most of my friends either have two or three roommates some people live in co-ops which means theyre living with about 10 to 12 people just to afford living here in the city um I have quite a few co-workers have had to actually leave the city to afford rent

question: What challenges do families face in San Francisco regarding housing and education?
answer: Families with two or three children find it unaffordable to pay for the type of schooling they want in the city in addition to rent.
source_text: just due to access to schooling for their children um they have two or three children and its just not affordable to pay for the type of schooling that they want in the city in addition to rent

question: How does Ariana Wilson describe the impact of housing costs on her family?
answer: If it wasn't for the building her grandma owned at a somewhat prated rent, Ariana would not be able to afford her own place in the city on her income.
source_text: so if it wasnt for the building that my grandma owned at somewhat of a prated rent I would not be able to probably afford my own place in the city on the income that I have

question: What is the housing situation for Ariana Wilson's father?
answer: Ariana's father, a retired union plumber, would not be able to afford living in San Francisco on his retirement and Social Security income.
source_text: my father was a union plumber for the last last 30 years with the city and county of San Francisco he has since then retired and based on what he makes on retirement and Social Security it would not be attainable for him to live here in this city

question: What is the living situation of Ariana Wilson's youngest sister?
answer: Ariana's youngest sister is living at home with their mom due to the high cost of rent.
source_text: so my youngest sister she got home from college a couple years ago and is still living at home with our mom due to the fact that rent is so expensive

question: What was the residency requirement for the San Francisco Fire Department?
answer: The San Francisco Fire Department used to have a residency requirement that you had to be a San Francisco resident to work there, which was in place due to susceptibility to natural disasters like earthquakes.
source_text: yeah so the San Francisco Fire Department used to have a residency requirement which meant that you had to be a San Francisco resident to work here and in part that was in place due to the fact that we are susceptible to natural disasters specifically earthquakes

question: What changes have occurred in the Panhandle region where Ariana Wilson grew up?
answer: The Panhandle region has seen a shift with churches no longer active due to lack of funding and people moving away, leading to a change in community dynamics.
source_text: but in the later part of our Lives we spent a lot of time near the Panhandle and growing up there were churches that were active which no longer are partially because of the lack of funding or people that previously lived there that actually used to um go to church they no longer live there

question: What was the impact of housing policies on the African-American community in Ariana Wilson's neighborhood?
answer: There was a mass exodus of the African-American community due to promises of affordable housing that were not fulfilled, leading to a shift in the community.
source_text: the neighborhood I grew up in was predominantly African-American and probably when I was about 12 or 13 um there was this Mass Exodus and people were told that were staying in kind of affordable housing that if they left and came back Renovations would have a place for them and that really wasnt the case

question: How does Ariana Wilson describe the change in community dynamics in her neighborhood?
answer: Ariana describes a shift from a close-knit community where neighbors knew each other to a more isolated environment where knocking on a neighbor's door is met with suspicion.
source_text: as a kid we had our local corner store and everybody knew us by first name basis we had grandparents that kind of looked out for us and houses that we could go in and out of and now the neighborhood that I live in you knock on a neighbors door and you try and say hello and its kind of welcom with a what are you doing

question: What challenges does Ariana Wilson face in buying property in San Francisco?
answer: Ariana finds properties in San Francisco far out of range financially, forcing her to consider looking in other communities outside of the Bay Area.
source_text: but even currently trying to look at properties for myself to even think about buying theyre so far out of range that I have to and Im almost forced to start looking in other communities outside of the Bay Area

question: What does Ariana Wilson consider a resource-rich neighborhood?
answer: A resource-rich neighborhood would have access to a good library, places of prayer, a safe community center, good education, and public schools with good reviews.
source_text: while resource neighborhood to me would mean having access to a good and running Library a place of prayer if that is something that is important to somebodys religious beliefs a safe Community Center good education a good public school with good reviews

question: What disparities does Ariana Wilson observe between different neighborhoods in San Francisco?
answer: Ariana observes stark differences in resources between well-populated, financially supported communities and those that aren't, such as Noe Valley versus Bayview Hunters Point.
source_text: but there is a stark difference between the well populated well financially supported communities versus ones that arent right so if we look at lets say noi Valley versus Bay View Hunters Point bayew Hunters Point has all has been an environment where you do not have access to the resources that any other community in the city does

question: What is Ariana Wilson's view on the development of resources in Bayview Hunters Point?
answer: Ariana questions why it takes an influx of money for resources to be built in Bayview Hunters Point, a disparity known since her childhood.
source_text: and as we see that and as we see an influx of money moving there we see more resources being built but something that iol question is why is it it take why does it take that in order for these resources to be built but this has been something that ever since I was a kid we knew existed

question: What is the community response to building housing in specific neighborhoods?
answer: There is often backlash against building housing in specific neighborhoods, such as the old Children's Hospital site, which has been vacant for years.
source_text: yeah I know theres always a kickback and a pushback for building housing in specific neighborhoods for instance the old Childrens Hospital has been vacant now for I want to say a number of years and this would be a great place to create housing and theres been a lot of backlash from the neighborhood

question: What are some issues people in the city are fed up with?
answer: People are fed up with issues like homelessness and poverty.
source_text: saying they dont want that type of housing in their neighborhood but these are also people that are communicating theyre really fed up with certain issues that were experiencing in the city like homelessness and poverty

question: What does Ariana Wilson believe is important for the city to do collectively?
answer: Ariana believes it's important for the city to come together and make a decision collectively to look out for the best interest of everybody that lives in the city.
source_text: there needs to be a point in which the city comes together and makes a decision collectively that we are looking out for the best interest of everybody that lives in the city

question: Why is it important to provide affordable and sustainable living in San Francisco?
answer: It's important to provide affordable and sustainable living for the folks that live in San Francisco, including those who serve the city like First Responders, because the city relies heavily on them.
source_text: I think that its really important that everybody is is a part of providing a affordable sustainable way of living for the folks that live in San Francisco and I think the same way that we approach homelessness and creating resources and providing safe places for people to live you also need to provide a safe place for the people that serve the city because what do we do without them as First Responders you guys heavily rely on us

question: What neighborhoods in San Francisco does Ariana Wilson find unaffordable?
answer: Ariana finds neighborhoods like Pacific Heights, Noe Valley, and the Mission unaffordable.
source_text: there are a handful of neighbor neighborhoods my whole life that have not been available or affordable for me like Pacific Heights is a gorgeous neighborhood that has tons of resources it has tons of space its clean its quiet but Ill never be able to afford living there Id say even noi Valley a neighborhood that has tons of great schooling it has really safe places for children to hang out if youre looking to raise a family Id love to live in but I wouldnt be able to afford it the mission is slowly changing to a place that I can no longer afford to live in

question: What does Ariana Wilson suggest to improve housing affordability in San Francisco?
answer: Ariana suggests more loans for first-time home buyers, better management and distribution of taxes towards housing, and more open-mindedness around diversifying the city.
source_text: I know that we have a program in place for firsttime home buyers in the city which really creates an amazing opportunity but that isnt enough based on the budget that they have for the majority of people in the city that do not make an income that matches the the needs of match it doesnt match the pricing of the housing market and so Id love to see more loans like that that were put in place Id love to see um I guess more of an attempt to manage and kind of disperse taxes that were paying towards housing because we pay very very steep expensive taxes in the city and we dont really see it reflected in how they provide affordability in housing um Id love to see there be more agreement and cohesiveness among people that are kind of preventing development in neighborhoods that they are trying to preserve um and more opened more open-mindedness around diversifying a city that really used to be extremely diverse and inclusive

question: What does Ariana Wilson appreciate about her current neighborhood?
answer: Ariana appreciates the accessibility and central location of her neighborhood, which is near the Panhandle and Golden Gate Park, and its proximity to other parts of the city.
source_text: I really appreciate the accessibility of my neighborhood Im right near the Panhandle at the moment um and I appreciate the ability to get outside and have access to like a beautiful walk through the park and access to Golden Gate Park there are still a few old bars if youre into that whether you drink or you dont drink that provide really great music and art um it is accessible and really really centralized to everything in the city the Castro is extremely close the richm is really close you head a little bit further and you have lower pack Heights even further than that youre heading kind of towards Japan town and so I love how centralized my neighborhood is

question: What does Ariana Wilson feel is missing from her neighborhood?
answer: Ariana feels that her neighborhood is missing a sense of community and diversity.
source_text: but something that its really missing is kind of the sense of community and the iers diversity and having had spent time there as a child and just seeing so many different people of so many different walks of life

question: How has the demographic of Ariana Wilson's neighborhood changed over time?
answer: The demographic of Ariana's neighborhood has shifted to being predominantly Caucasian, with less vibrance and diversity than before.
source_text: now demographically my neighborhoods predominantly Caucasian um a little blended with a little bit of Asian-American or you know Asian descent but you dont see as much of that Vibrance and that diversity and mix of different backgrounds

question: What changes has Ariana Wilson observed in the Mission and Western Addition neighborhoods?
answer: Ariana observed that the Mission used to have a vibrant Hispanic community, and the Western Addition was predominantly African-American with a strong jazz culture, but these have been lost due to people being priced out.
source_text: the mission specifically used to have a very big community of Hispanic um Central South American communities right you had a lot of people from Nicaragua El Salvador Mexico Peru Bolivia and thats really been lost and I think there was this vibrancy and community that was just really phenomenal and amazing there were a lot of families based there there was a lot of music there was a lot of art there was a lot of culture and the Western Edition in Filmore predominantly used to be African-American and within that you had the Jazz Community jazz festivals you had tons of vibrant amazing lovely food and music and we losing a lot of that throughout the city which is really unfortunate

question: What does Ariana Wilson consider a thriving community?
answer: A thriving community is one that provides clean eating, access to music, education, arts, creativity, safe learning spaces, diversity, healthcare, and cultural resources.
source_text: Id say a thriving Community looks like one that is able to provide clean eating right whether that be farmers markets and locally sourced food whether that be having a place like Whole Foods that offers organic non GMO options a thriving Community to me entails having access to music and education and arts and creativity and safe places of learning um a thriving Community also means having people that dont look like you its important to be exposed to folks that come up from different backgrounds than you do um that means also having accessibility to healthcare and or health clinics not just onetime visits hospitals Museums Art culture

question: What is Ariana Wilson's vision for housing in the city?
answer: Ariana envisions a city where people who grew up and contributed to the city can afford to buy a house or live comfortably, whether in an apartment or a house.
source_text: Id love to have a city where people that grew up here and contributed and continued to contribute to the city had the option to buy a house or live in a place that they comfortably could consider home whether that be an apartment and thats all that youve ever aspired to have whether that be a three-bedroom house because thats all youve ever wanted in your life before but also just having a clean affordable safe comfortable way of life
